Sated with home, of wife, of children tired,</br>The restless soul is driven abroad to roam;</br>Sated abroad, all seen, yet nought admired,</br>The restless soul is driven to ramble home;</br>Sated with both, beneath new Drury's dome</br>The fiend Ennui awhile consents to pine,</br>There growls, and curses, like a deadly Gnome,</br>Scorning to view fantastic Columbine,</br>Viewing with scorn and hate the nonsense of the Nine.

Ye reckless dupes, who hither wend your way,</br>To gaze on dupes who meet an equal doom,</br>Pursuing pastimes glittering to betray,</br>Like falling stars in life's eternal gloom,</br>What seek ye here?  Joy's evanescent bloom?</br>Woe's me!  the brightest wreaths she ever gave</br>Are but as flowers that decorate a tomb,</br>Man's heart, the mournful urn o'er which they wave,</br>Is sacred to despair, its pedestal the grave.

Has life so little store of real woes,</br>That here ye wend to taste fictitious grief?</br>Or is it that from truth such anguish flows</br>Ye court the lying drama for relief?</br>Long shall ye find the pang, the respite brief,</br>Or if one tolerable page appears</br>In folly's volume, 'tis the actor's leaf,</br>Who dries his own by drawing other's tears,</br>And raising present mirth, makes glad his future years.

Albeit how young Betty doth he flee?</br>Light as the mote that daunceth in the beam,</br>He liveth only in man's present 'ee,</br>His life a flash, his memory a dream,</br>Oblivious down he drops in Lethe's stream:</br>Yet what are they, the learned and the great?</br>A while of longer wonderment the theme!</br>Who shall presume to prophecy their date,</br>Where nought is certain, save th' uncertainty of fate?

This goodly pile upheav'd by Wyatt's toil,</br>Perchance than Holland's edifice more fleet,</br>Again red Lemnos' artisan may spoil;</br>The fire alarm, and midnight drum may beat,</br>And all be strewed ysmoking at your feet.</br>Start ye?  Perchance Death's angel may be sent</br>Ere from the flaming temple ye retreat,</br>And ye who met on revel idlesse bent</br>May find in Pleasure's fane your grave and monument.

Your debts mount high — ye plunge in deeper waste,</br>The plaintiff calls — no warning voice ye hear;</br>The plaintiff sues — to public shews ye haste;</br>The bailiff threats — ye feel no idle fear;</br>Who can arrest your prodigal career?</br>Who can keep down the levity of youth?</br>What sound can startle age's stubborn ear?</br>Who can redeem from wretchedness and ruth</br>Men true to falsehood's voice, false to the voice of truth?

To thee, blest saint!  who doff'd thy skin to make</br>The Smithfield rabble leap from theirs with joy,</br>We dedicate the pile — arise!  awake!—</br>Knock down the muses, wit and sense destroy,</br>Clear our new stage from reason's dull alloy,</br>Charm bubbling age, and tickle capering youth,</br>With cleaver, marrow bone, and Tunbridge toy;</br>While, vibrating in unbelieving tooth,</br>Harps twang in Drury's walls, and make her boards a booth.

For what is Hamlet, but a hare in march?</br>And what is Brutus, but a croaking owl?</br>And what is Rolla?  Cupid steep'd in starch,</br>Orlando's helmet in Augustine's cowl.</br>Shakespear, how true thy adage, "fair is foul;"</br>To him whose soul is with fruition fraught,</br>The song of Braham is an Irish howl,</br>Thinking is but an idle wast of thought,</br>And nought is every thing, and every thing is nought.

Sons of Parnassus!  whom I view above,</br>Not laurel crown'd, but clad in rusty black,</br>Not spurring Pegasus through Tempe's grove,</br>But pacing Grub-street on a jaded hack.</br>What reams of foolscap, while your brains ye rack,</br>Ye mar to make again!  for sure, ere long,</br>Condemned to tread the bards time-sanctioned track,</br>Ye all shall wail in poverty your wrong,</br>And reproduce in rags the rags ye blot in song.

So fares the bard who sings in fashion's train,</br>He toils to starve, and only lives in death;</br>We slight him till our patronage is vain,</br>Then round his skeleton wind laurel wreath,</br>And o'er his bones a balmy requiem breathe—</br>Oh!  with what tragic horror would he start</br>(Could he be conjur'd from the grave beneath)</br>To find the stage again a Thespian cart,</br>And elephants and colts down trample Shakespear's art.

Hence, pedant Nature!  with thy Grecian rules,</br>Centaurs (not fabulous) those rules efface,</br>Back, sister muses, to your native schools;</br>Here booted grooms usurp Apollo's place,</br>Hoofs shame the boards that Garrick used to grace;</br>The play of limbs succeeds the play of wit;</br>Man yields the drama to the Houynim race,</br>His prompter spurs, his licencer the bit,</br>The stage a four in hand, a jockey club the pit.

Is it for these ye rear this proud abode?</br>Is it for these your superstition seeks</br>To build a temple worthy of a god,</br>To laud a monkey, or to worship leeks?</br>Then be the stage, to recompense your freaks,</br>A motley chaos, jumbling age and ranks,</br>Where Punch, the lignum vitae Roscius, squeaks,</br>And Wisdom weeps, and Folly plays his pranks,</br>And moody Madness laughs, and hugs the chain he clanks.</br>
